section.name: Introduction
section.p:
This document describes how to publish a data collection using an Astrogrid Datacenter Server. To do this, carry out the following steps:
Install the system pre-requisites
Download PAL
Deploy PAL
Configure the database
Configure the connection to the data collection
Create a description of the data collection
Restart the servlet container
Test the installation
Add the data collection with the Astrogrid Registry

section.name: Pre-requisites
section.p: This page describes the software components that must be installed and configured before installing the Datacenter Server. The Datacenter Server relies upon the following software components, which must be installed and configured before installing the Datacenter Server.

section.name: Download PAL
section.p:
The publishers astrogrid library is distributed as a J2EE Web Application (.war) file named pal.war To add a dependency on PAL to your own project, add the following to your maven project.xml
<dependencies> ... <dependency> <groupId>astrogrid-datacenter</groupId> <artifactId>pal</artifactId> <version>SNAPSHOT</version> <type>war</type> </dependency> ... <dependencies>
Alternately, the latest snapshot of PAL can be downloaded directly from
http://www.astrogrid.org/maven/astrogrid-datacenter/wars/pal-SNAPSHOT.war

Or the latest stable release (It4.1) from
http://www.astrogrid.org/maven/astrogrid-datacenter/wars/pal-Itn04_1.war

body.section:
You can use the Tomcat manager to install PAL (see the Tomcat manager instructions) or you can do it by hand:
$ cp pal.war ${CATALINA_HOME}/webapps
Copy pal.war to the webapps directory of your tomcat installation and restart your server:
$ ${CATALINA_HOME}/bin/shutdown.sh $ ${CATALINA_HOME}/bin/startup.sh
Once tomcat has been restarted, the pal web application will be unpackaged into the directory webapps/pal. If installed on your machine in the default location, the web application root will be http://localhost:8080/pal.

section.name: Configure PAL
section.p:
This page describes in detail how to configure your datacenter. However once PAL has been installed, it should be possible to run the installation tests and some cone queries on it, as it contains a simple SQL database by default.
Read the configuration page before going on, as you will need to make a new configuration file to connect to your data.

You need to write a description of the data collection provided by your installation. This document should conform to (what schema?) The location of this file can be set in the configuration file. The default location is metadata.xml on the classpath.

section.name: Verify the installation
section.p: Pal comes packaged with a series of self-test scripts. To run these, visit the web application root, and navigate to the self-test page. Inspect the result from each script - no errors should appear on the output.

subsection.name: Logging
subsection.p:
The datacenter uses 'commons-logging' to log messages; on a Tomcat server this is routed to the server's Log4J logger. A default log4j properties file is included in the distribution, and can be found at /WEB-INF/classes/log4j.properties in the web application.
By default, the properties file causes INFO and higher messages to go to std.out (these can be found in the catalina.out file when using Tomcat), INFO and higher messages are stored in pal.log, and DEBUG and higher messages are stored in a rolling file (it is size limited) called pal-debug.log. These latter two are found in ${CATALINA_HOME}/logs/ when running under Tomcat.

subsection.name: Running test queries
subsection.p:
The datacenter web application contains a simple web form that submits a query to the datacenter service.
In addition, the client delegate jar contains simple command-line tool that will fire a adql query at the server and display the VOTABLE response. You need to write an adql query that conforms to the adql schema (downloadable from the web application) and save it to a file.
$ java org.astrogrid.datacenter.ui.DatacenterCommander adql <url-endpoint> <query-xml-file>
